content:
I've seen a few like this. The email is written using HTML and usually there is a load of tables inside tables and the view source code looks a mess. If you have an email that is having this problem do the following and you should be able to get a print out.

View > Message Body as > select 'Simple HTML' then select email and use the Print.

content:
re : In older versions you could right click on a folder

There would not be any options in a 'folder' which would effect specific emails let alone offer a delete option.

Maybe you are talking about removing all old hidden traces of emails you have already deleted or moved and you want to clean up the file storage.

  • Right click on folder and select 'Compact'.

How to delete selected emails:

  • Hold down 'Ctrl key and use mouse to select/highlight specific emails.
  • They are shown as 'X messages' in the lower Message Pane area and a 'Delete' button is offered as an option.

OR

  • Hold down 'Ctrl key and use mouse to select/highlight specific emails.
  • Right click on highlighted emails in Message List and select 'Delete selected emails'

OR

  • Hold down 'Ctrl key and use mouse to select/highlight specific emails.
  • Press the 'Delete' key on keyboard.

Alternative option:

  • In Message List - enable the 'Delete' column header so you see a bin icon for email.
  • click on the 'bin' icon associated with each email in list you want to delete

Remember - after deleting a lot of emails. I would suggest you compact the folder in order to clean up the storage file.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I notice that when I select one message or a conversation, I have different action in the header pane. When it's multiple messages selected, I only have Archive and Delete as option.

That is correct. It has always been the options when multiple emails are selected.

So I want to have the same choice as single message selected.

That's not possible because the message Header Pane is email specific for an opened email - it shows the header information of an email and a group of selected emails shown as X Conversations or Messages is not an email specific option. It is not the Header Pane.

What you can do is right click on the selected/highlighted emails in the upper 'Message List/Thread Pane' area and then you have many options such as 'Copy to'.

The link you mentioned is now out of date for 115* . Actually, it was out of date for 102* as well. Select an email and in Header Pane you will see a 'More' button which offers options. At the bottom is a 'Customise' option. This faciliates some customisation such as only show icons. It only effects the 'Header Pane' and not the 'X Messages' pane.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If you always want pdfs to open using SumatraPDF On computer:

  • In search type 'Default' and select 'Default apps'
  • select 'Choose default applications by file type'
  • scroll down to .pdf
  • click on whatever option is currently set to see list of option
  • Select SumatraPDF

In Thunderbird:

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll down to 'Files & Attachments'
  • Content type: PDF
  • click on it's action and choose SumatraPDF. If it's not list then click on 'Use Other' and locate the SumatraPDF exe file.

It should use that option, but restart Thunderbird to ensure all files have been updated.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I am not familiar with Proton mail, but if their AllMail folder is like Gmail's, then it represents a duplication of messages in other folders. For Gmail users, my recommendation is to unsubscribe from AllMail, as it often causes confusion. In Gmail accounts, the AllMail folder is administered by Gmail, not the user. I respect this information may be of no use if Proton's structure is different.

creator: DorothyJ

content:
On computer: In Display - 'size of apps and text on main display use 100% recommended. What screen resolution are you using on computer? I'm using Display resolution: 1920x1080 Suggest you keep everything as normal and we'll then tackle Thunderbird separately.

In Thunderbird Set things to default: Via 'Menu Bar' toolbar - View > Font Size >select 'Reset font size' Via 'Menu app icon' - Font Size - click on the numberpx which is located between the + and the -

Have you gone into the config editor and altered the pixels size ? If yes, then go back and use the far right reset icon to set it as default negative -1.0 If required we can tackle the font and pixel etc as a separate issue.

re :If I try to drag the panel upward with the mouse it only goes a third of the way up,

This sound like you are trying to drag the top header/splitter upwards to reveal more of the 'Message Pane and reduce the number of lines you see in the 'Message List'.

I know there has been a change in the code and it's causing some problems in access to Message Pane and reading emails. Developers increased the min height to 200px which is just not suitable for some people and even I found it annoying.

Go to this link and follow the instructions to change that min height from 200px down to what works for you. I use 150px but others prefer 100px.

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1423733
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Fantastic! You saved me a lot of grief, and saved me days of frustration. It was the most in depth solution I've ever attempted in all my years working with computers (1990, DOS5 and Netscape ). 

This did the trick.

I did drop the pixels down to 100, now I can resize the window and read my whole message, With only a few clicks of the mouse wheel. 

I have an Acer EI342CKR wide screen, 3440 X 1440 (Recommended) with an Intel 750 video card 8GB.

After making the changes in Thunderbird, I was able to change the scale back to a 175% which I normally use, (100% is actually unreadable without a Binoculars!) I will save all this information for a later date, Thanks again Keith Johnson

creator: oranji

content:
If you right-click the Unified bar, Customize..., a Get Messages button can be dragged onto the bar. Clicking that button fetches mail for all accounts, as does Shift+F5. Clicking the cloud icon on the Header bar gets messages for the current account, like F5, or right-clicking allows choosing the account.

There are various userChrome options to hide, move or resize the toolbars, and e.g. move the app menu icon to the left side. The customization is maybe not as easy as many would like, but it is possible.
creator: sfhowes

content:
I repeat, they took a very convenient option, moved it to a very inconvenient place, and hid it. Not my idea of an "upgrade."

The other part of my question, how to EXCLUDE a specific account from the all-messages download, has not been addressed. There used to be an option in the account settings for that, which has now disappeared. With the expanding number of people now managing multiple email addresses, some of which may be work addresses that they do not wish to monitor in their off-work hours, this seems like a really inappropriate time to remove that option.

In my case, I have an old account that receives almost entirely spam, but which I wish to keep, as it my only means of connection with certain correspondents. Since it receives multiple spam messages every day, I REALLY don't want those downloading in real time, which renders it impossible to tell from the notification bubble how many real messages I have. For years, it has been my practice to manually download them once a month, and clean out the spam messages. The "include this server when getting new mail" checkbox used to be an option for accounts with their own inbox, but apparently now it is only available for accounts using the global inbox (which all of my other accounts do). I don't want to send the mostly spam messages from this account to my global inbox to get intermixed with all my other mail.

Every time there is a major update of Thunderbird, options I use every day are suddenly deleted, disrupting my workflow, sometimes in a major way, and leaving me with the unavoidable impression that Mozilla is seriously out of touch with real-world usage of Thunderbird, and not very interested in correcting that, or even seeing it as a problem.
creator: oranji

content:
Why do you want to build Thunderbird 118 specifically? If you're looking for a bleeding edge version, consider 119 (because it will be easier to package) or sticking with the 115 ESR (this is already packaged for you).

If you really want to package 118 as a deb, I suggest starting from the most recent deb package available for debian experimental. Once you can build the available 117 deb, you can make the changes necessary for 118.

How to build 117 (on a Debian system)

First off, make a working directory

$ mkdir thunderbird-deb-build && cd thunderbird-deb-build

As with any debian packaging, you'll need the orig tarball. For reasons I'll explain in a bit, you should just download this tarball from the thunderbird package in experimental on packages.debian.org . You should also download the l10.tar.xz tarball since it is needed for the thunderbird build. Either click the links from the website or wget them.

~/thunderbird-deb-build$ wget http://deb.debian.org/debian/pool/main/t/thunderbird/thunderbird_117.0~b5.orig.tar.xz ~/thunderbird-deb-build$ wget http://deb.debian.org/debian/pool/main/t/thunderbird/thunderbird_117.0~b5.orig-thunderbird-l10n.tar.xz

Since this package is built with git-buildpackage (gbp), you'll want to go clone the debian source repository. And since the repository is so large you'll need to increase the git postBuffers (I set mine to the max git clone size of 10Gb) before cloning:

~/thunderbird-deb-build$ git config --global http.postBuffer 10737418240 ~/thunderbird-deb-build$ git config --global https.postBuffer 10737418240 ~/thunderbird-deb-build$ git clone https://salsa.debian.org/mozilla-team/thunderbird.git

Note that the tarballs need to be one level up from the cloned source. I've set it up this way but it's worth being explicit about the placement.

Also note that there is a script that generated the tarballs you downloaded, debian/create-upstream-tarballs.py (you see in your cloned repo). This script can generate the latest released ESR tag or the latest beta so I assume this script was run when 117 was the latest beta. Since the latest beta has moved onto 119, this script will no longer generate the 117 tarballs. That is why I have directed you to just download them from the packages.debian.org site.

Since we'll be using gbp, there's some local clone structure needed in preparation so checkout a few branches and make sure you have local branches tracking the remote ones:

~/thunderbird-deb-build$ cd thunderbird ~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ git checkout debian/upstream ~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ git checkout debian/experimental


If the branch isn't automatically tracking the upstream repo's branch do that with “git branch -u”

gbp uses a pristine-tar branch but since I think the maintainers forgot to push the pristine tarball that is provided on the packages.debian.org site, you need to make that local commit (it takes a while, maybe 20 min):

~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ gbp pristine-tar commit ../thunderbird_117.0~b5.orig.tar.xz

Since we are going to use pbuilder as their README recommends, we need to setup pbuilder:

~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ DIST=sid git-pbuilder create

Now just make sure you have all of the build dependencies installed and you are ready to build the thunderbird 117.0~b5 package: ~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ sudo apt-get build-dep thunderbird ~/thunderbird-deb-build/thunderbird$ gbp buildpackage --git-pbuilder

How to build 118.0b6 (on a Debian system)

Now that you have the general steps for building and setup with the cloned repo and pbuilder environment, you'll need to use it to build a newer 118 tarball. Since you've chose a version that is not supported by the script that makes the tarballs (debian/create-upstream-tarballs.py), you'll need to recreate that logic to generate a thunderbird_118.0~b6.orig.tar.xz and thunderbird_118.0~b6.orig-thunderbird-l10n.tar.xz. Perhaps you can just hack on this script to allow the 118.0b6 version.

You can find the original sources published by Thunderbird for this version here:

https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/118.0b6/linux-x86_64/

Once you have the two tarballs, one level up from the git cloned source, then you can proceed with the same building steps to ideally build a 118 deb.

How to build 119 (on a Debian system)

Use the debian/create-upstream-tarballs.py and choose the 119 option to generate your tarballs. Once you have the two tarballs, you can proceed with the same building steps to build a 119 deb.

I hope that this helps you achieve your goal :)
creator: linuxflower
